docs.title: TUI Dashboard Options - Interactive Terminal UI
docs.text: Context: Day 8-9 implementation for Interactive TUI Dashboard Created: 2025-12-23 Estimated Effort: 2-3 hours

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Create a beautiful, interactive Terminal User Interface (TUI) dashboard for the flow-cli status command. This dashboard will provide real-time session monitoring, project selection, and quick actions through an intuitive terminal interface.

docs.title: Option 1: Blessed (Most Popular) ⭐ RECOMMENDED
docs.text: Library: blessed (11.9k stars) Philosophy: Full-featured terminal interface library (like ncurses for Node.js)

docs.title: Pros
docs.text:
• ✅ Most mature and widely used TUI library
  • ✅ Rich widget set (boxes, lists, tables, progress bars, forms)
  • ✅ Built-in keyboard and mouse support
  • ✅ Easy styling with CSS-like syntax
  • ✅ Excellent documentation and examples
  • ✅ Works in any terminal (no external dependencies)
  • ✅ Active community and plugins (blessed-contrib for charts)

docs.title: Cons
docs.text:
• ⚠️ Larger bundle size (~100KB)
  • ⚠️ Steeper learning curve for complex layouts
  • ⚠️ Some quirks with terminal compatibility

docs.title: Code Example
docs.text:
import blessed from 'blessed'

// Create screen
const screen = blessed.screen({
  smartCSR: true,
  title: 'Flow CLI Dashboard'
})

// Active session box
const sessionBox = blessed.box({
  top: 0,
  left: 0,
  width: '100%',
  height: 8,
  border: { type: 'line' },
  style: {
    border: { fg: 'green' },
    focus: { border: { fg: 'cyan' } }
  },
  label: ' 🔥 Active Session ',
  content: 'Project: rmediation\nTask: Fix tests\nDuration: 45 min'
})

// Project list
const projectList = blessed.list({
  top: 8,
  left: 0,
  width: '50%',
  height: '100%-8',
  border: { type: 'line' },
  style: {
    selected: { bg: 'blue' }
  },
  keys: true,
  vi: true,
  items: ['rmediation', 'quarto-doc', 'flow-cli']
})

// Render
screen.append(sessionBox)
screen.append(projectList)
screen.render()

// Quit on Escape, q, or Control-C
screen.key(['escape', 'q', 'C-c'], () => process.exit(0))

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Complex dashboards with multiple widgets
  • Interactive forms and menus
  • Real-time data updates
  • Custom key bindings

docs.title: Effort: ~2-3 hours
docs.text:
• Layout: 30 min
  • Widgets: 1 hour
  • Interactivity: 30 min
  • Styling: 30 min
  • Testing: 30 min

docs.title: Option 2: Ink (React for CLI) 🎨
docs.text: Library: ink (26.8k stars) Philosophy: Build TUIs with React components

docs.title: Pros
docs.text:
• ✅ Use React components and hooks (familiar for React devs)
  • ✅ Declarative UI (easier to reason about)
  • ✅ Hot reload during development
  • ✅ Built-in components (Box, Text, Newline)
  • ✅ Smaller learning curve if you know React
  • ✅ Great for simple, focused UIs
  • ✅ Auto-testing with ink-testing-library

docs.title: Cons
docs.text:
• ⚠️ Requires React knowledge
  • ⚠️ Heavier (React runtime overhead)
  • ⚠️ Less control over low-level terminal features
  • ⚠️ Overkill for simple dashboards

docs.title: Code Example
docs.text:
import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react'
import { render, Box, Text } from 'ink'

const Dashboard = () => {
  const [session, setSession] = useState(null)

  useEffect(() => {
    // Fetch session data
    const interval = setInterval(() => {
      // Update session
    }, 1000)
    return () => clearInterval(interval)
  }, [])

  return (
    <Box flexDirection="column">
      <Box borderStyle="round" borderColor="green" padding={1}>
        <Box flexDirection="column">
          <Text bold color="green">
            🔥 Active Session
          </Text>
          <Text>Project: {session?.project}</Text>
          <Text>Duration: {session?.duration} min</Text>
        </Box>
      </Box>

      <Box borderStyle="round" marginTop={1} padding={1}>
        <Box flexDirection="column">
          <Text bold color="cyan">
            📊 Today
          </Text>
          <Text>Sessions: 5</Text>
          <Text>Duration: 3h 45m</Text>
        </Box>
      </Box>
    </Box>
  )
}

render(<Dashboard />)

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• React developers
  • Simple, focused dashboards
  • Rapid prototyping
  • Component reusability

docs.title: Effort: ~2 hours
docs.text:
• Components: 1 hour
  • State management: 30 min
  • Styling: 30 min

docs.title: Option 3: Terminal-Kit (Feature Rich) 🛠️
docs.text: Library: terminal-kit (3.1k stars) Philosophy: Full terminal manipulation library

docs.title: Pros
docs.text:
• ✅ Extremely feature-rich (animations, images, menus)
  • ✅ Better graphics support (can display images in terminal)
  • ✅ Progress bars, spinners, tables out of the box
  • ✅ Document-based API (easier than blessed)
  • ✅ Built-in input handling (text fields, yes/no, menus)

docs.title: Cons
docs.text:
• ⚠️ Less popular (smaller community)
  • ⚠️ Heavy (larger API surface)
  • ⚠️ Some features require specific terminals

docs.title: Code Example
docs.text:
import terminalKit from 'terminal-kit'
const term = terminalKit.terminal

// Clear and position
term.clear()

// Session box
term.cyan('╭─ 🔥 Active Session ─────────────╮\n')
term.cyan('│ ').green('Project: rmediation          ').cyan('│\n')
term.cyan('│ ').yellow('Duration: 45 min              ').cyan('│\n')
term.cyan('╰──────────────────────────────────╯\n\n')

// Interactive menu
term.green('Select project:\n')
const items = ['rmediation', 'quarto-doc', 'flow-cli']

term.singleColumnMenu(items, (error, response) => {
  term('\n').green(`Selected: ${items[response.selectedIndex]}`)
})

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Rich graphics in terminal
  • Interactive menus and forms
  • Progress tracking with spinners
  • Image display in supported terminals

docs.title: Effort: ~2 hours
docs.text:
• Setup: 15 min
  • UI elements: 1 hour
  • Interactivity: 45 min

docs.title: Option 4: Charm Bubbletea (Go-inspired) 🫧
docs.text: Library: bubbletea (JavaScript port: not official) Note: Primarily a Go library, but Elm Architecture concepts apply

docs.title: Pros
docs.text:
• ✅ Elm Architecture pattern (Model-View-Update)
  • ✅ Predictable state management
  • ✅ Great for complex interactive apps
  • ✅ Composable and testable

docs.title: Cons
docs.text:
• ⚠️ No official JavaScript port
  • ⚠️ Would need to build from scratch using the pattern
  • ⚠️ Steeper learning curve

Recommendation: Use blessed or ink instead for JavaScript projects.

docs.title: blessed-contrib (Charts for Blessed) 📊
docs.text:
Library: blessed-contrib Use with: blessed

Features:

  • Line charts
  • Bar charts
  • Donut charts
  • Sparklines
  • Tables
  • Maps
  • Logs

Code Example:

import blessed from 'blessed'
import contrib from 'blessed-contrib'

const screen = blessed.screen()

const grid = new contrib.grid({ rows: 12, cols: 12, screen })

// Line chart
const line = grid.set(0, 0, 6, 12, contrib.line, {
  label: 'Session Duration Trend',
  showLegend: true,
  style: {
    line: 'yellow',
    baseline: 'white'
  }
})

// Bar chart
const bar = grid.set(6, 0, 6, 6, contrib.bar, {
  label: 'Projects by Sessions',
  barWidth: 4,
  barSpacing: 6,
  maxHeight: 9
})

// Donut chart
const donut = grid.set(6, 6, 6, 6, contrib.donut, {
  label: 'Completion Rate',
  radius: 8,
  arcWidth: 3
})

// Update data
line.setData([
  { title: 'This Week', x: ['Mon', 'Tue', 'Wed', 'Thu', 'Fri'], y: [30, 45, 60, 40, 50] }
])

screen.render()

Effort: +1 hour to add charts to blessed dashboard

docs.title: ink-ui (UI Components for Ink) 🎨
docs.text:
Library: ink-ui Use with: ink

Features:

  • Select menu
  • Multi-select
  • Progress bar
  • Spinner
  • Text input

Code Example:

import React from 'react'
import { render } from 'ink'
import { Select } from 'ink-ui'

const Demo = () => (
  <Select
    items={[
      { label: 'rmediation', value: 'rm' },
      { label: 'quarto-doc', value: 'qd' },
      { label: 'flow-cli', value: 'fc' }
    ]}
    onSelect={item => {
      console.log(`Selected: ${item.label}`)
    }}
  />
)

render(<Demo />)

docs.title: Why This Combination?
docs.text:
1. Mature ecosystem - Battle-tested in production
  2. Rich widgets - Everything we need out of the box
  3. Charts support - blessed-contrib for visualizations
  4. No React overhead - Pure terminal manipulation
  5. Excellent examples - Many open-source dashboards to reference

docs.title: Implementation Plan (2-3 hours)
docs.text:
Phase 1: Basic Layout (1 hour)

  • Setup blessed screen
  • Create session box
  • Create today stats box
  • Create project list
  • Basic keyboard navigation

Phase 2: Charts (30 min)

  • Add blessed-contrib
  • Line chart for trend
  • Donut chart for completion rate
  • Real-time updates

Phase 3: Interactivity (45 min)

  • Keyboard shortcuts (f, p, s, r, q)
  • Project selection with Enter
  • Auto-refresh every 5 seconds
  • Status updates on actions

Phase 4: Polish (30 min)

  • Color scheme (match current CLI colors)
  • Border styles
  • Loading states
  • Error handling

docs.title: Alternative: Hybrid Approach 🎯
docs.text:
Use both blessed AND current CLI:

  1. Default: Enhanced status command (what we built today)
  2. Optional flag: flow status --tui launches blessed dashboard
  3. Best of both worlds: Fast CLI + rich TUI when needed

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• Users choose their preference
  • CLI remains fast and scriptable
  • TUI available for deep dives
  • No breaking changes

docs.title: Implementation

// cli/commands/status.js
if (options.tui) {
  const { TUIController } = await import('../adapters/controllers/TUIController.js')
  const controller = new TUIController(getStatusUseCase)
  await controller.launch()
} else {
  // Current StatusController
}

docs.title: Why?
docs.text:
1. ✅ No breaking changes to CLI
  2. ✅ Users choose their interface
  3. ✅ Best tool for each use case
  4. ✅ Rich charts and widgets available

docs.text:
If implementing TUI:

  1. Install dependencies
npm install blessed blessed-contrib

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
Recommended path: Implement hybrid approach with blessed + blessed-contrib

Estimated effort: 3 hours total

  • blessed setup: 1 hour
  • Charts: 30 min
  • Interactivity: 1 hour
  • Testing & polish: 30 min

Benefits:

  • Choice for users (CLI vs TUI)
  • Rich visualizations
  • ADHD-friendly interface
  • Professional dashboard
  • Production-ready library

When to skip TUI:

  • Time constraints (CLI alone is excellent)
  • Prefer web dashboard instead
  • Focus on other features first

The enhanced CLI status command we built today is already production-ready and provides great value. The TUI is an optional enhancement for users who want a richer terminal experience.

docs.title: Context-Aware Commands
docs.text:
# When inside an R package directory:
$ cd ~/projects/r-packages/active/medfit
$ p .                    # Shows R package info
$ p check                # Runs R CMD check (detected R package)
$ p test                 # Runs devtools::test()
$ p doc                  # Runs devtools::document()

# When inside a Quarto project:
$ cd ~/projects/quarto/manuscripts/paper1
$ p .                    # Shows Quarto project info
$ p render               # Runs quarto render
$ p preview              # Runs quarto preview

# When inside a dev-tool:
$ cd ~/projects/dev-tools/claude-mcp
$ p .                    # Shows project info
$ p test                 # Runs npm test (detected package.json)

Pros:

  • Single command to learn
  • Works everywhere
  • Context-aware reduces typing
  • Scales to any number of projects

Cons:

  • Lots of subcommands to remember
  • May feel too abstract
  • p alone might be too minimal

docs.title: Context Detection
docs.text:
# Automatic test command based on project type:
$ pt

# In R package → Rscript -e 'devtools::test()'
# In npm project → npm test
# In Python → pytest
# In Make project → make test
# In Quarto → quarto check

  • Minimum keystrokes
  • Visual picker reduces memory load
  • Context detection = less typing
  • Very ADHD-friendly (no decisions)

Cons:

  • Requires fzf
  • Less explicit (magic can confuse)
  • Harder to script

#!/usr/bin/env zsh
# extract-function.sh - Extract function ranges from adhd-helpers.zsh

SOURCE_FILE="$HOME/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh"
TARGET_DIR="$HOME/.config/zsh/functions/helpers"

extract_function() {
    local func_name="$1"
    local start_line="$2"
    local end_line="$3"
    local target_file="$4"

    echo "Extracting $func_name (lines $start_line-$end_line) to $target_file"

    # Extract function
    sed -n "${start_line},${end_line}p" "$SOURCE_FILE" >> "$target_file"
    echo "" >> "$target_file"  # Add blank line after function
}

docs.title: Research: Status/State Management in Developer Tools
docs.text: Date: 2025-12-14 Purpose: Find better alternatives to confusing status command Current Problem: status does 3 things (show/update/create) - unclear what action it performs

docs.title: The Core Problem
docs.text:
Your status command suffers from action ambiguity:

  • No arguments = interactive update (NOT show!)
  • --show flag = show current status
  • --create flag = create new .STATUS file
  • 5+ arguments = quick update

The confusion: Users expect status (noun) to show state, not change it.

docs.title: Key Finding
docs.text: Best practice: Separate commands by action (verbs) > Combined commands with modes

docs.title: 1. Git - The Gold Standard
docs.text:
Command Structure:

git status              # NOUN - Shows current state (read-only)
git add                 # VERB - Modifies state
git commit              # VERB - Modifies state
git show                # VERB - Shows something
git config --get        # VERB + flag for action
git config --set        # VERB + flag for action

Pattern: VERB-first commands with nouns as objects

  • status is READ-ONLY (the exception - it's a noun that only reads)
  • All state changes are VERBS (add, commit, push, pull, merge)
  • When verbs have multiple modes, flags clarify (--get vs --set)

Key Insight: The word "status" has been claimed by Git to mean "show current state, read-only"

ADHD Score: 9/10

  • Clear verbs = clear actions
  • git status is universally understood as "show me what's happening"
  • No ambiguity about what will change

docs.title: 2. GitHub CLI (gh) - Resource-Based
docs.text:
Command Structure:

gh pr view              # RESOURCE + ACTION
gh pr create            # RESOURCE + ACTION
gh pr edit              # RESOURCE + ACTION
gh issue list           # RESOURCE + ACTION
gh repo view            # RESOURCE + ACTION

Pattern: RESOURCE + VERB (noun + verb)

  • First word = what you're working with (pr, issue, repo)
  • Second word = what you're doing to it (view, create, edit, list)

ADHD Score: 8/10

  • Two-word structure is longer but very clear
  • Auto-complete friendly
  • Scales well (many resources, many actions)

docs.title: 3. npm/yarn - Mixed Patterns
docs.text:
Command Structure:

npm install             # VERB
npm run                 # VERB
npm list                # VERB
npm view                # VERB
npm config get          # NOUN + VERB
npm config set          # NOUN + VERB

Pattern: Mix of VERB-first and RESOURCE + VERB

  • Simple commands are verbs (install, run, list)
  • Complex subsystems use resource+verb (config get/set)

ADHD Score: 7/10

  • Mostly consistent
  • config get/set is clear but longer
  • Some verbs are non-obvious (view vs show vs list)

docs.title: 4. tmux - Verbose but Clear
docs.text:
Command Structure:

tmux show-options       # VERB-NOUN (show what?)
tmux set-option         # VERB-NOUN (set what?)
tmux display-message    # VERB-NOUN
tmux list-sessions      # VERB-NOUN

Pattern: VERB-NOUN compounds (hyphenated)

  • Very explicit
  • Self-documenting
  • Long but unambiguous

ADHD Score: 6/10

  • Very clear what each command does
  • Too long for frequent use
  • Excellent for discoverability

docs.title: 5. cargo (Rust) - Verb-First
docs.text:
Command Structure:

cargo build             # VERB
cargo test              # VERB
cargo run               # VERB
cargo update            # VERB
cargo check             # VERB

Pattern: Pure VERB commands

  • All actions are verbs
  • Short and memorable
  • Context (Rust project) provides the noun

ADHD Score: 9/10

  • Ultra-clear action words
  • Short commands
  • No ambiguity

docs.title: 6. kubectl - Resource-Based with Complexity
docs.text:
Command Structure:

kubectl get pods        # VERB + RESOURCE
kubectl describe pod    # VERB + RESOURCE
kubectl edit pod        # VERB + RESOURCE
kubectl apply           # VERB (resource in file)
kubectl delete pod      # VERB + RESOURCE

Pattern: VERB + RESOURCE (opposite of gh)

  • Verb first (what to do)
  • Resource second (what to do it to)

ADHD Score: 8/10

  • Clear action verbs
  • Flexible resource types
  • Can be verbose

docs.title: 7. Task Management Tools
docs.text:
taskwarrior:

task add                # VERB
task list               # VERB
task done               # VERB
task modify             # VERB

todo.txt:

todo.sh add             # VERB
todo.sh list            # VERB
todo.sh do              # VERB

Pattern: VERB commands for actions

ADHD Score: 9/10 (taskwarrior), 8/10 (todo.txt)

  • Simple verbs
  • Memorable
  • Clear intent

docs.title: Pattern Summary Table
docs.text: Tool Pattern Show Command Update Command ADHD Score Git VERB-first git status git add/commit 9/10 GitHub CLI RESOURCE+VERB gh pr view gh pr edit 8/10 npm Mixed npm list npm install 7/10 tmux VERB-NOUN tmux show-options tmux set-option 6/10 cargo Pure VERB (build shows) cargo update 9/10 kubectl VERB+RESOURCE kubectl get kubectl edit 8/10 taskwarrior VERB task list task modify 9/10

docs.title: 1. Action Clarity
docs.text:
Good:

  • show - I will see something
  • update - I will change something
  • create - I will make something new

Bad:

  • status - Will it show or change? Unclear!
  • manage - Too vague
  • handle - What does this do?

docs.title: 2. Verb > Noun for Actions
docs.text:
Good:

  • update-status (verb first)
  • show-status (verb first)

Bad:

  • status --update (noun first, action hidden in flag)
  • status (noun, action unclear)

docs.title: 3. Consistency Wins
docs.text:
• If you use show-X, use update-X (not change-X)
  • If you use get-X, use set-X (not put-X)
  • Parallel structure aids memory

docs.title: 4. Short Commands for Frequent Use
docs.text:
• Daily use: 1-4 characters ideal (js, dash, work)
  • Weekly use: 4-8 characters acceptable
  • Rare use: Longer is OK if self-documenting

docs.title: 5. Avoid Multi-Mode Commands
docs.text:
Bad pattern:

status            # Interactive update
status --show     # Show
status --create   # Create

Better pattern:

pshow             # Project show (or: dash)
pupdate           # Project update
pcreate           # Project create

docs.title: Current Problem Analysis
docs.text:
Your status command:

status mediationverse              # → Interactive UPDATE (unexpected!)
status mediationverse --show       # → Show (expected, but needs flag)
status mediationverse --create     # → Create (unexpected from "status")
status medfit active P1 "Task" 60  # → Quick UPDATE (reasonable)

Why it's confusing:

  1. Default behavior is UPDATE, not SHOW (violates Git's status convention)
  2. Name is a NOUN, but primary action is a VERB (update)
  3. Multi-mode with hidden actions
  4. Requires flags to do the "obvious" thing (show)

docs.title: Solution Option A: Pure VERB Commands
docs.text:
Separate everything:

pshow <project>                    # Show status (or use existing 'dash')
pupdate <project>                  # Interactive update
pset <project> <status> <pri>...   # Quick update
pinit <project>                    # Create new .STATUS

Pros:

  • Crystal clear action words
  • No ambiguity
  • Follows Git/cargo pattern
  • Easy to remember (all start with 'p')

Cons:

  • More commands to remember
  • pshow duplicates dash functionality

ADHD Score: 9/10

docs.title: Solution Option B: Keep Short, Split Actions
docs.text:
Use your existing pattern of ultra-short commands:

dash [project]                     # KEEP - Show status (already exists)
pup <project>                      # Project update (interactive)
pup <project> <status> <pri>...    # Project update (quick)
pinit <project>                    # Project init (create .STATUS)

Pros:

  • dash already handles "show" perfectly
  • pup = "project update" (clear verb)
  • Only 2 new commands (pup, pinit)
  • Follows your 1-char to 4-char philosophy

Cons:

  • "pup" might be too cute
  • Could conflict with Python's pip

ADHD Score: 8/10

docs.title: Solution Option C: Resource-Based (gh style)
docs.text:
Use 'project' as the resource:

proj show <name>                   # Show status
proj update <name>                 # Interactive update
proj set <name> <status> <pri>...  # Quick update
proj init <name>                   # Create .STATUS

Pros:

  • Follows GitHub CLI pattern (familiar)
  • Self-documenting
  • Expandable (could add proj list, proj search, etc.)
  • Clear namespace

Cons:

  • Two-word commands (longer)
  • Duplicates dash for show

ADHD Score: 7/10 (clear but verbose)

docs.title: Solution Option D: Hybrid (Recommended)
docs.text:
Keep best of current, minimize changes:

dash [project]                     # KEEP - Show all or one project
up <project>                       # Update status (interactive)
up <project> <status> <pri>...     # Update status (quick)
pinit <project>                    # Create .STATUS (rare operation)

Changes from current:

  • Rename status → up (ultra-short verb)
  • Remove status --show (use dash instead)
  • Keep status --create as pinit (project init)

Pros:

  • Minimal disruption (status → up)
  • up is clear verb (update)
  • Ultra-short for daily use (2 chars!)
  • Leverages existing dash command
  • Only one command to change

Cons:

  • up might conflict with uptime or other tools
  • Not as self-documenting as longer names

ADHD Score: 9/10 ⭐ RECOMMENDED

docs.title: Solution Option E: Context-Aware Single Command
docs.text:
Make behavior obvious from arguments:

set <project>                      # Interactive update (no other args)
set <project> <status> <pri>...    # Quick update (has args)
init <project>                     # Create .STATUS (different command)
# For show: use existing 'dash'

Pros:

  • set is universally understood (Git uses it)
  • Clear verb for changing state
  • Context determines mode (interactive vs quick)
  • Only 2 commands total

Cons:

  • Can't show with same command (but dash handles this)

ADHD Score: 8/10

docs.title: Comparison Matrix
docs.text: Solution Show Update Create Total Commands ADHD Score Current status --show status status --create 1 (multi-mode) 5/10 Option A pshow pupdate pinit 3 9/10 Option B dash pup pinit 2 new 8/10 Option C proj show proj update proj init 1 (multi-mode) 7/10 Option D ⭐ dash up pinit 2 new 9/10 Option E dash set init 2 new 8/10

docs.title: Primary Recommendation: Ultra-Short Verbs
docs.text:
# SHOW - Use existing command
dash                               # Show all projects
dash mediationverse                # Show one project

# UPDATE - New ultra-short verb
up <project>                       # Interactive update
up medfit active P1 "Docs" 60      # Quick update

# CREATE - Rare operation, can be longer
pinit <project>                    # Project init (create .STATUS)

Why this wins:

  1. Leverages existing dash (no duplication)
  2. up is 2 chars (ultra-fast for daily use)
  3. up clearly means "update" (verb)
  4. pinit is rare, longer name is fine
  5. Minimal migration (one command rename)

docs.title: Alternative: Slightly More Explicit
docs.text:
If up feels too short, consider:

dash [project]                     # Show (existing)
pset <project> ...                 # Project set (like git config set)
pinit <project>                    # Project init

docs.title: Alternative: Match Your Workflow
docs.text:
Look at your other workflow commands:

work <name>                        # Start work (verb)
finish [msg]                       # End work (verb)
js                                 # Just start (verb)
dash                              # Dashboard (noun, but read-only)

Pattern: Your successful commands are mostly VERBS!

Match this pattern:

dash [project]                     # Keep (exception: noun, read-only)
track <project>                    # Track project status (update)
start <project>                    # Start new project (create)

docs.title: 1. Semantic Release ✅
docs.text:
File: .releaserc.json

Automated versioning and changelog generation based on conventional commits.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Automated Versioning: Determines next version based on commit messages
  • Changelog Generation: Creates CHANGELOG.md automatically
  • GitHub Releases: Creates GitHub releases with release notes
  • npm Publishing: Publishes to npm registry (if configured)
  • Git Tagging: Automatically tags releases

docs.title: Conventional Commit Types
docs.text: Type Release Description feat: Minor New feature fix: Patch Bug fix perf: Patch Performance improvement docs: Patch Documentation only (with README scope) refactor: Patch Code refactoring style: Patch Code style changes chore(deps): Patch Dependency updates BREAKING CHANGE: Major Breaking API changes

docs.title: Commit Message Format
docs.text:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>

<body>

<footer>

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Minor release (new feature)
git commit -m "feat(cli): add project picker command"

# Patch release (bug fix)
git commit -m "fix(status): resolve timing calculation error"

# Major release (breaking change)
git commit -m "feat(api)!: redesign status API

BREAKING CHANGE: StatusController.getStatus() now returns Promise"

# No release (chore)
git commit -m "chore: update README formatting"

docs.title: Release Workflow
docs.text:
Trigger: Push to main branch

Process:

  1. Analyze commits since last release
  2. Determine version bump (major/minor/patch)

docs.title: Tutorial: Your First Flow Session
docs.text:
What you'll build: Track and complete your first focused work session using Flow CLI

Time: ~15 minutes | Level: Beginner

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Have Flow CLI installed (~/.config/zsh/ directory exists)
  • [ ] Have at least one project in ~/projects/
  • [ ] Know how to use terminal and ZSH

Verify your setup:

# Check Flow CLI is installed
ls ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh

# Check you have projects
ls ~/projects/

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Start a focused work session on a project
  2. Track your progress during the session
  3. Use project context commands
  4. End the session and save your work

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Flow CLI helps you stay focused by tracking work sessions. Here's the workflow:

┌────────────────┐     ┌────────────────┐     ┌────────────────┐
│  Pick Project  │ --> │   Work on It   │ --> │  End Session   │
│  (just-start)  │     │   (commands)   │     │   (finish)     │
└────────────────┘     └────────────────┘     └────────────────┘

docs.title: Step 1.1: Check What's Available
docs.text:
Let's see what projects you can work on:

dash

What happened: You see a dashboard showing all your projects organized by status (Active, Ready, Paused, Blocked).

Example output:

╭─────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ 🎯 YOUR WORK DASHBOARD                      │
╰─────────────────────────────────────────────╯

🔥 ACTIVE NOW (2):
  📦 flow-cli [P0] 95% - Documentation improvements
  📚 stat-440 [P1] 60% - Grade assignments

📋 READY TO START (1):
  📊 research-project [P2] 20% - Literature review

docs.title: Step 1.2: Let Flow Pick For You
docs.text:
Instead of deciding, let Flow choose based on priority:

just-start

What happened: Flow automatically selects your highest-priority active project and shows you the details:

🎲 Finding your next task...

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ 🎯 DECISION MADE FOR YOU                    │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Project: 📦 flow-cli                        │
│ Type:    dev-tools                          │
│ Reason:  P0 priority (critical)             │
│ Next:    Documentation improvements         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────┘

💡 Quick actions:
   work .        = Start working
   status .      = Update status
   dash          = See all projects

📁 /Users/dt/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli

Note: Flow picks based on: P0 active → P1 active → any active → most recent

docs.title: Step 1.3: Start Working
docs.text:
Now open the project in your editor:

work .

What happened: Flow detects the project type and opens the appropriate editor (VS Code, RStudio, Emacs, etc.).

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should have:

  • [x] Viewed your dashboard
  • [x] Let Flow pick a project
  • [x] Opened the project in your editor

Verify:

pwd
# Expected: You're in the project directory

docs.title: Step 2.1: Start a Timed Session
docs.text:
Now set a focus timer to stay on track:

f25

What happened: A 25-minute Pomodoro timer starts. Your terminal shows a countdown.

Example output:

🍅 Pomodoro Timer Started!
⏱️  25:00 remaining...

[Terminal shows countdown in prompt]

Tip: Use f50 for a 50-minute deep work session instead

docs.title: Step 2.2: Check Your Context
docs.text:
If you forget what you're working on:

why

What happened: Shows your current project context:

📍 CURRENT CONTEXT

Project:  flow-cli
Type:     dev-tools
Location: /Users/dt/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli
Status:   ACTIVE (P0)
Task:     Documentation improvements
Progress: 95%

Active since: 14 minutes ago

docs.title: Step 2.3: Work on Your Task
docs.text:
Now do your actual work! For example:

  • Edit files in your editor
  • Run tests
  • Write documentation
  • Code features

Project-specific commands:

# For R packages
rload        # Load package
rtest        # Run tests
rdoc         # Generate docs

# For development projects
npm test     # Run tests
npm run build # Build project

# Git workflow
gst          # Check status (git status)
ga .         # Stage changes (git add .)
gcmsg "msg"  # Commit (git commit -m "msg")

docs.title: Step 2.4: Log Your Wins
docs.text:
When you accomplish something:

win "Completed first Flow tutorial"

What happened: Your accomplishment is logged to track progress.

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should have:

  • [x] Started a focus timer
  • [x] Checked your context
  • [x] Done actual work
  • [x] Logged at least one win

Verify:

wins
# Expected: See your logged wins for today

docs.title: Step 3.1: Update Your Progress
docs.text:
Before ending, update the project status:

status .

What happened: Flow asks for updates interactively:

📋 UPDATE STATUS: flow-cli
═══════════════════════════════════════════

Current values shown in [brackets]

Status? [active]
   (active/paused/blocked/ready)
> active

Priority? [P0]
   (P0=critical, P1=important, P2=normal)
> P0

Next task? [Documentation improvements]
> Complete tutorial files

Progress? [95]
   (0-100)
> 100

✅ Updated! Press Enter to continue...

Tip: Press Enter to keep current values, only type when you want to change something

docs.title: Step 3.2: Commit Your Changes
docs.text:
If you made code changes, commit them:

gst          # Check what changed
gaa          # Stage all changes
gcmsg "docs: add first session tutorial"

docs.title: Understanding Session Tracking
docs.text:
Flow CLI tracks your work sessions in ~/.config/zsh/.worklog:

Field Meaning project Current project name start_time When you started working duration How long you've been working task What you're currently doing

This helps you:

  • Remember where you left off
  • Track time spent on projects
  • Generate progress reports

docs.title: Tutorial: Tracking Multiple Projects
docs.text:
What you'll build: Manage and switch between multiple active projects efficiently

Time: ~20 minutes | Level: Intermediate

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Completed: Tutorial 1: Your First Flow Session
  • [ ] Have 3+ projects in ~/projects/
  • [ ] Understand basic dash and status commands

Verify your setup:

# Check you have multiple projects
dash | grep -E "ACTIVE|READY"

# Should see at least 2-3 projects

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Organize projects by category and priority
  2. Switch between projects efficiently
  3. Use filtering to focus on specific work
  4. Balance multiple projects without overwhelm

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Managing multiple projects is common - you might have:

  • Teaching + Research + Package development
  • Multiple client projects
  • Personal projects + Work projects

Flow CLI helps you juggle these without losing track:

┌──────────────┐     ┌──────────────┐     ┌──────────────┐
│  All Projects│ --> │Filter Category│ --> │ Work on One │
│   (dash)     │     │  (dash X)     │     │   (work X)   │
└──────────────┘     └──────────────┘     └──────────────┘

docs.title: Step 1.1: View All Projects
docs.text:
Start by seeing everything:

dash

Note: Too many active projects? This is common - we'll fix it!

Let Flow pick based on priority:

  1. P0 + active (most urgent)
  2. P1 + active (important)

Too many active projects? Pause the less urgent ones:

Review and adjust priorities:

# Important (this week)

# Normal (when you can)
status medfit paused P2 "Resume later" 30

Priority guidelines:

Priority Meaning How many? P0 Critical, urgent 1-2 max P1 Important 2-3 P2 Normal Unlimited

Warning: More than 2 P0 projects = everything is urgent = nothing is urgent

When interrupted:

just-start

docs.title: Exercise 1: Balance Your Projects
docs.text:
Review your active projects and balance them.

Goal: 2-4 active projects max, rest paused/ready

Hint Run `dash`, count active projects. Pause anything not P0/P1 or not immediately actionable. Solution 
# 1. View current state
dash

# 2. Pause low-priority active projects

status causal-inference paused P2 "Next semester" 0

# 3. Keep only critical/important active
status mediationverse active P0 "Final push" 85
status stat-440 active P0 "Urgent grading" 60

# 4. Verify

docs.title: Exercise 2: Category-Based Day
docs.text:
Plan a day focusing on one category.

Solution

f50
# ... work ...

# Afternoon: Research focus

f50
# ... work ...

docs.title: Exercise 3: Emergency Project
docs.text:
Handle an urgent new project without losing track of current work.

Solution 
# 1. Pause current project
cd ~/projects/current-project
status . paused P1 "Emergency interrupt - resume ASAP" 60

# 2. Create new urgent project
cd ~/projects/urgent-project
status urgent-project --create
status urgent-project active P0 "Critical fix" 0

# 3. Work on it
work .
# ... fix the issue ...
status . active P0 "Fixed critical bug" 100

# 4. Mark complete and return
status . ready P2 "Done - archive if needed" 100

# 5. Resume original work
work current-project
status . active P1 "Resume work" 60

docs.title: "Too many active projects"
docs.text:
Cause: Everything marked as active

Fix:

Cause: No time blocks

Fix:

# Afternoon: Research

# Use timers to enforce focus

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you learned:

Concept What You Did Filtering Used dash <category> to focus Switching Used work, pick, just-start States Paused, blocked, activated projects Priorities Set P0/P1/P2 realistically Workflows Category-based and priority-based

docs.title: Tutorial: Using Status Visualizations
docs.text:
What you'll build: Understanding and using visual progress indicators effectively

Time: ~15 minutes | Level: Intermediate

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Completed: Tutorial 2: Tracking Multiple Projects
  • [ ] Have projects with progress tracked (0-100%)
  • [ ] Understand basic status command

Verify your setup:

# Check you have projects with progress
dash | grep "%"

# Should see percentage values for projects

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Read and interpret progress bars
  2. Use progress tracking to stay motivated
  3. Understand project metrics and statistics
  4. Create accurate progress estimates

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Flow CLI uses visual indicators to make progress tangible:

┌───────────────┐     ┌───────────────┐     ┌───────────────┐
│  Update %     │ --> │  See Progress │ --> │ Stay Motivated│
│  (status)     │     │   (dash)      │     │   (wins)      │
└───────────────┘     └───────────────┘     └───────────────┘

Visual feedback helps ADHD-friendly workflows by:

  • Making abstract progress concrete
  • Providing dopamine hits when bars fill up
  • Showing momentum across multiple projects

docs.title: Step 1.1: Basic Progress Display
docs.text:
View a project's progress:

dash

What you'll see:

🔥 ACTIVE NOW (3):
  📦 mediationverse [P0] 85% - Final simulations
  📚 stat-440 [P1] 60% - Grade midterms
  🔧 flow-cli [P2] 95% - Documentation

Progress breakdown:

Range Color Meaning 0-25% Red Just started 26-50% Yellow Making progress 51-75% Cyan Over halfway 76-99% Green Almost done 100% Bright Green Complete!

docs.title: Step 1.2: Detailed Progress Bars
docs.text:
Some commands show full progress bars:

# View detailed status (if implemented)
status mediationverse --show

What you might see:

📦 mediationverse
═══════════════════════════════════════════

Status:   🔥 ACTIVE
Priority: [P0] Critical
Progress: ████████████████░░░░ 85%
Task:     Final simulations
Updated:  2025-12-24

Recent progress:
  Dec 20: 60% → 70% (+10%)
  Dec 22: 70% → 80% (+10%)
  Dec 24: 80% → 85% (+5%)

docs.title: Step 1.3: Category Summaries
docs.text:
See aggregate progress:

dash teaching

What you'll see:

╭─────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ 🎯 TEACHING PROJECTS (2)                    │
│ Average progress: 45%                       │
╰─────────────────────────────────────────────╯

🔥 ACTIVE (2):
  📚 stat-440 [P0] 60% - Grade midterms
  📚 causal-inference [P2] 30% - Prep syllabus

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should understand:

  • [x] Progress percentage colors
  • [x] How to view progress in dashboard
  • [x] What different ranges mean

Verify:

dash | grep "%"
# Expected: See projects with different progress levels

docs.title: Step 2.1: Starting a New Project (0%)
docs.text:
When starting fresh:

cd ~/projects/new-project
status new-project --create
status new-project ready P2 "Initial setup" 0

What happened: Project created at 0%:

📋 READY TO START (1):
  📊 new-project [P2] 0% - Initial setup

docs.title: Step 2.2: Small Incremental Updates
docs.text:
Update progress in small chunks:

# First day: Basic setup
status new-project active P2 "Setup environment" 10

# Next day: Start coding
status new-project active P2 "First feature" 25

# Week later: Halfway
status new-project active P2 "Core complete" 50

Why small increments?

  • More accurate than big jumps
  • More frequent dopamine hits
  • Easier to estimate remaining work

docs.title: Step 2.3: The 80-20 Rule
docs.text:
Many projects follow this pattern:

0-80%:   Fast progress (easy work)
80-95%:  Slow progress (hard/tedious work)
95-100%: Very slow (polish, edge cases)

Example progression:

# Week 1-2: Fast progress
status project active P1 "Core features" 80

# Week 3: Slows down
status project active P1 "Bug fixes" 85

# Week 4: Tedious work
status project active P1 "Edge cases" 90

# Week 5: Final polish
status project active P1 "Documentation" 95

# Week 6: Complete
status project ready P2 "Done!" 100

Tip: Don't be discouraged when 80-100% takes as long as 0-80%!

docs.title: Step 2.4: Progress Milestones
docs.text:
Set checkpoints:

Progress Milestone Task Example 0% Planning "Define scope and requirements" 25% Foundation "Basic setup complete" 50% Core "Main features implemented" 75% Integration "Everything connected" 90% Polish "Bug fixes and cleanup" 100% Done "Ready for release"

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should:

  • [x] Know how to track new projects
  • [x] Understand incremental updates
  • [x] Recognize the 80-20 pattern

Verify:

# Update a project with new milestone
status . active P1 "Reached 75% milestone" 75
dash
# Expected: See updated progress

docs.title: Step 3.1: Celebrate Progress
docs.text:
When you cross milestones:

# Hit 50%!
status . active P0 "Halfway done!" 50
win "Reached 50% on mediationverse package!"

# Hit 75%!
status . active P0 "Almost there!" 75
win "75% complete - final push!"

# Hit 100%!
status . ready P2 "Complete!" 100
win "COMPLETED mediationverse package!!!"

docs.title: Step 3.2: Track Velocity
docs.text:
How fast are you progressing?

# Monday
status project active P1 "Start work" 10

# Friday
status project active P1 "Week complete" 30

# Velocity: 20% per week
# Estimate: 3.5 weeks to complete (70% remaining / 20% per week)

Track in your task description:

status project active P1 "Week 2 - on track (+20%)" 30

docs.title: Step 3.3: Use Visual Momentum
docs.text:
Seeing multiple projects advance creates momentum:

# Before (Monday)
dash
# mediationverse: 65%
# stat-440: 40%
# flow-cli: 80%

# After (Friday)
dash
# mediationverse: 75% ⬆️ +10%
# stat-440: 60% ⬆️ +20%
# flow-cli: 90% ⬆️ +10%

win "Productive week! All projects advanced!"

docs.title: Step 3.4: Handle Setbacks
docs.text:
Sometimes progress goes backward:

# Discovered major bug, need to redo work
status project active P0 "Fix critical bug - set back" 70

# Previous was 85%, now 70% (-15%)

This is OK! Accurate progress > inflated numbers.

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should:

  • [x] Celebrate milestones with win
  • [x] Track velocity (% per week)
  • [x] Use visual momentum
  • [x] Handle setbacks honestly

Verify:

wins
# Expected: See celebration wins for milestones

docs.title: Technique 1: Sub-Project Breakdown
docs.text:
For large projects, track components:

# Main project
status mediationverse active P0 "Package development" 75

# Mental breakdown (not tracked in tool):
# - Core functions: 90% (mostly done)
# - Tests: 80% (good coverage)
# - Documentation: 60% (needs work)
# - Vignettes: 50% (in progress)
# Average: (90+80+60+50)/4 = 70%

# Update based on weighted average
status mediationverse active P0 "Focus on docs/vignettes" 70

docs.title: Technique 2: Must-Have vs Nice-to-Have
docs.text:
Adjust progress based on scope:

# Original plan (100% = everything)
status project active P1 "All features" 60

# Scope reduction (100% = must-haves only)
status project active P1 "Core features only" 85

# Suddenly much closer to done!

docs.title: Technique 3: Time-Based vs Work-Based
docs.text:
Two ways to track:

Time-based (not recommended):

# Week 1 of 10 = 10%
status project active P1 "Week 1" 10

Work-based (recommended):

# 3 of 10 features done = 30%
status project active P1 "3/10 features" 30

Tip: Work-based is more accurate because work rarely distributes evenly over time.

docs.title: Technique 4: Done is Better Than Perfect
docs.text:
Don't wait for 100% perfection:

# 95% complete, could polish forever
status project active P1 "Good enough to ship" 95

# Ship it!
status project ready P2 "Shipped v1.0!" 100
win "Shipped project v1.0 - done is better than perfect!"

# Future improvements are a new project
status project-v2 ready P2 "Enhancements for v2" 0

docs.title: Exercise 1: Estimate a New Project
docs.text:
Break down and estimate a new project.

Hint List all major tasks, estimate time for each, calculate total, set milestones. Solution 
# New R package project
cd ~/projects/r-packages/active/newpackage

# Break down tasks:
# 1. Setup (5%) - 1 day
# 2. Core functions (30%) - 1 week
# 3. Tests (20%) - 3 days
# 4. Documentation (20%) - 3 days
# 5. Vignettes (15%) - 2 days
# 6. Final checks (10%) - 1 day

# Start tracking
status newpackage ready P2 "Planning complete" 0

# After setup
status newpackage active P1 "Package skeleton created" 5

# After core
status newpackage active P1 "Main functions working" 35

# Continue incrementally...

docs.title: Exercise 2: Recover from Setback
docs.text:
Handle a project that went backwards.

Solution 
# Before: thought you were at 80%
status project active P0 "Found major issue" 80

# After analysis: need to redo significant work
status project active P0 "Revising approach - realistic reset" 60

# Document why
win "Discovered issue early - better to fix now than later"

# Make steady progress forward
status project active P0 "Fixed root cause" 70
status project active P0 "Re-implemented correctly" 80
status project active P0 "Validated thoroughly" 90
status project ready P2 "Done right this time!" 100

docs.title: Exercise 3: Celebrate Milestones
docs.text:
Track and celebrate a project's key milestones.

Solution 
# 0%: Start
status project active P1 "Project started" 0
win "Started new project - excited to build this!"

# 25%: Foundation
status project active P1 "Foundation solid" 25
win "25% complete - strong foundation!"

# 50%: Halfway
status project active P1 "Halfway there!" 50
win "50% COMPLETE! - past the hardest part!"

# 75%: Polish phase
status project active P1 "Polishing now" 75
win "75% done - can see the finish line!"

# 100%: Complete
status project ready P2 "DONE!" 100
win "PROJECT COMPLETE! Shipped and proud!"

# View all celebrations
wins

docs.title: "Progress seems stuck"
docs.text:
Cause: Working on 80-100% phase (slow progress)

Fix:

# Break down remaining work into smaller tasks
# Update more frequently with smaller increments

# Instead of jumping from 85% to 90%:
status . active P1 "Fixed bug #1" 86
status . active P1 "Fixed bug #2" 87
status . active P1 "Added validation" 88

# Smaller wins feel better!

docs.title: "Not sure what percentage to use"
docs.text:
Cause: Unclear milestones

Fix:

# Use concrete milestones:
# 0%   = Planning
# 10%  = Setup complete
# 25%  = First feature working
# 50%  = Core features done
# 75%  = All features implemented
# 90%  = Testing/polish
# 100% = Complete and shipped

# Estimate based on work done vs work remaining

docs.title: "Progress feels arbitrary"
docs.text:
Cause: Not tracking concrete deliverables

Fix:

# Track specific completions:
status . active P1 "3 of 10 functions complete" 30
status . active P1 "7 of 15 tests passing" 47
status . active P1 "2 of 4 vignettes written" 80

# % = (completed / total) * 100

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you learned:

Concept What You Did Progress ranges Understood 0-25%, 26-50%, 51-75%, 76-99%, 100% Incremental tracking Updated in small chunks for accuracy The 80-20 rule Expected 80-100% to be slow Milestones Set and celebrated progress markers Motivation Used visual progress for dopamine Estimates Broke down work to calculate %

Key insights:

# Track progress incrementally
status . active P1 "Task complete (+5%)" 35

# Celebrate milestones
win "Reached 50%!"

# Be honest about setbacks
status . active P0 "Reset to fix properly" 60

# Ship at 95-100%, don't wait for perfection
status . ready P2 "Good enough!" 100

Progress tips:

  • Small increments - 5-10% updates feel more concrete
  • Celebrate milestones - 25%, 50%, 75%, 100%
  • Accept setbacks - Accurate % > inflated numbers
  • Ship it - 95%+ is often "done enough"

docs.text:
What you'll build: Using the browser-based dashboard for rich visualizations

node --version

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Launch and navigate the web dashboard
  2. Use interactive visualizations
  3. Filter and search projects
  4. Monitor real-time session data
  5. Export and share dashboard views

docs.text:
The web dashboard provides rich browser-based visualizations:

Benefits over terminal dashboard:

  • Charts and graphs (bar, line, pie)
  • Mouse/touch interaction
  • Larger screen real estate
  • Persistent view while you work
  • Shareable URLs

Cognitive Load:

Keystrokes:

Discoverability:

docs.title: Q: Why remove so many aliases?
docs.text: A: Based on frequency analysis, 151 aliases were used less than 10 times per day. The maintenance burden outweighed the benefit.

docs.title: Q: Can I keep using v1.0?
docs.text: A: Yes! v1.0 is tagged and will remain available. But you'll miss out on new features, help system, and better documentation.

docs.title: Q: Will v2.0 add more aliases later?
docs.text: A: Only if they meet the "10+ uses per day" rule and provide clear value. The focus is on quality over quantity.

docs.title: Q: What about the git plugin aliases?
docs.text: A: The OMZ git plugin provides 226+ git aliases. No need to maintain custom git aliases when a well-maintained plugin exists.

docs.title: Q: Are there performance improvements?

docs.title: Project Detection User Guide
docs.text: Feature: Automatic project type detection Status: ✅ Available now Difficulty: Beginner-friendly

docs.title: What is Project Detection?
docs.text:
Project detection automatically identifies what type of project you're working with by looking at files in your project directory. It can detect:

  • 📦 R Packages - Projects with DESCRIPTION files
  • 📄 Quarto Projects - Projects with _quarto.yml or .qmd files
  • 🔌 Quarto Extensions - Quarto plugin projects
  • 🔬 Research Projects - Projects with LaTeX, bibliographies
  • 📁 Generic Git Projects - Any project with .git
  • ❓ Unknown - Unrecognized project types

docs.title: Using the API (JavaScript/Node.js)
docs.text:
import { detectProjectType } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'

// Detect a single project
const type = await detectProjectType('/Users/dt/projects/r-packages/stable/rmediation')
console.log(`Project type: ${type}`) // "r-package"

docs.title: Using a CLI Tool (Coming Soon)
docs.text:
# Detect current directory
zsh-config detect

# Detect specific directory
zsh-config detect ~/projects/teaching/stat-440

docs.title: R Package (r-package)
docs.text:
Detected when:

  • Project has a DESCRIPTION file
  • DESCRIPTION contains Package: field

Example:

my-r-package/
├── DESCRIPTION       ← Must have "Package: mypackage"
├── R/
│   └── functions.R
├── man/
└── NAMESPACE

Detection:

const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/my-r-package')
// Returns: 'r-package'

docs.title: Quarto Project (quarto)
docs.text:
Detected when project has ANY of:

  • _quarto.yml file
  • _quarto.yaml file
  • index.qmd file
  • README.qmd file

Example:

my-quarto-project/
├── _quarto.yml       ← Configuration file
├── index.qmd         ← Homepage
└── chapters/
    ├── chapter1.qmd
    └── chapter2.qmd

Detection:

const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/my-quarto-project')
// Returns: 'quarto'

docs.title: Quarto Extension (quarto-extension)
docs.text:
Detected when project has:

  • _extension.yml file OR
  • _extensions.yml file

Example:

my-quarto-extension/
├── _extension.yml    ← Extension config
└── shortcode.lua

Note: Quarto extensions are detected before regular Quarto projects, so a project with both _extension.yml and _quarto.yml will be identified as an extension.

docs.title: Research Project (research)
docs.text:
Detected when project has ANY of:

  • main.tex (LaTeX main file)
  • manuscript.tex (Manuscript file)
  • literature/ directory
  • references.bib (Bibliography)

Example:

my-research/
├── manuscript.tex
├── references.bib    ← Any of these triggers detection
├── figures/
└── literature/       ← Research papers directory

Detection:

const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/my-research')
// Returns: 'research'

docs.title: Generic Git Project (generic)
docs.text:
Detected when:

  • Project has a .git directory
  • Doesn't match any more specific type

Example:

my-project/
├── .git/            ← Git repository
├── README.md
└── src/
    └── code.js

Detection:

const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/my-project')
// Returns: 'generic'

docs.title: Unknown (unknown)
docs.text:
Returned when:

  • Project doesn't match any known type
  • Path doesn't exist
  • Permission denied

Example:

const type1 = await detectProjectType('/nonexistent/path')
// Returns: 'unknown'

const type2 = await detectProjectType('/random/folder')
// Returns: 'unknown' (no .git, no markers)

docs.title: Problem: Returns 'unknown' for valid project
docs.text:
Cause: Project doesn't have the expected marker files

Solution: Check for marker files:

# R package needs DESCRIPTION with Package: field
cd /path/to/project
grep "^Package:" DESCRIPTION

# Quarto needs _quarto.yml or .qmd files
ls -la _quarto.yml *.qmd

# Research needs LaTeX or bibliography
ls -la *.tex references.bib literature/

# Git project needs .git directory
ls -la .git

If markers exist but detection still fails, check file permissions:

chmod +r DESCRIPTION _quarto.yml  # Make files readable

docs.title: Problem: "Permission denied" errors
docs.text:
Cause: Node.js process can't read project directory

Solution: Ensure read permissions:

# Check permissions
ls -la /path/to/project

# Fix permissions
chmod +r /path/to/project
chmod +rx /path/to/project  # Also need execute for directories

docs.title: Problem: Detection is slow
docs.text:
Cause: Detecting many projects sequentially

Solution: Use batch detection:

// ❌ Slow: Sequential
for (const path of allPaths) {
  const type = await detectProjectType(path) // Waits for each
}

// ✅ Fast: Parallel batch
const types = await detectMultipleProjects(allPaths) // All at once

Performance:

  • Sequential (10 projects): ~200-300ms
  • Parallel (10 projects): ~50-100ms
  • 3x faster with batch detection!

docs.title: Problem: Need to detect custom project types
docs.text:
Status: Not yet supported (coming in Phase 2)

Workaround: Use generic detection and add your own logic:

const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/project')

// Add custom logic
if (type === 'generic') {
  // Check for custom markers
  if (existsSync(join(projectPath, 'cargo.toml'))) {
    return 'rust'
  }
  if (existsSync(join(projectPath, 'go.mod'))) {
    return 'go'
  }
}

docs.title: ✅ Do
docs.text:
• Use batch detection for multiple projects (faster)
  • Handle 'unknown' type gracefully in your application
  • Use absolute paths for reliability
  • Check isTypeSupported() before using type in logic

docs.title: ❌ Don't
docs.text:
• Don't detect sequentially when you have multiple projects
  • Don't throw errors on 'unknown' type (it's expected)
  • Don't use relative paths (may give unexpected results)
  • Don't assume types - always call the API

docs.title: Build a Project Dashboard
docs.text:
import { detectMultipleProjects } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'
import { readdir } from 'fs/promises'
import { join } from 'path'

async function buildDashboard(baseDir) {
  // Scan all subdirectories
  const entries = await readdir(baseDir, { withFileTypes: true })
  const dirs = entries.filter(e => e.isDirectory()).map(e => join(baseDir, e.name))

  // Detect all types in parallel
  const types = await detectMultipleProjects(dirs)

  // Group by type
  const grouped = {}
  for (const [path, type] of Object.entries(types)) {
    if (!grouped[type]) grouped[type] = []
    grouped[type].push({
      name: path.split('/').pop(),
      path: path
    })
  }

  return grouped
}

// Usage
const dashboard = await buildDashboard('/Users/dt/projects/r-packages/stable')

console.log(`R Packages: ${dashboard['r-package']?.length || 0}`)
console.log(`Quarto Projects: ${dashboard['quarto']?.length || 0}`)

import { detectProjectType } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'

async function runBuild(projectPath) {
  const type = await detectProjectType(projectPath)

  switch (type) {
    case 'r-package':
      console.log('Running R CMD build...')
      // R package build logic
      break

    case 'quarto':
      console.log('Running quarto render...')
      // Quarto render logic
      break

    case 'research':
      console.log('Compiling LaTeX...')
      // LaTeX compilation logic
      break

    default:
      console.log('Generic build process...')
    // Default build logic
  }
}

docs.text: rdoc && rtest        # Document then test

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Change @param docs → rdoc && rtest → Docs regenerate → Tests run → ✅

docs.title: What This Does
docs.text:
1. ⏱️ [3-5s] Regenerates .Rd files from roxygen
  2. ⏱️ [3-5s] Updates NAMESPACE exports
  3. ⏱️ [2-4min] Runs all tests

docs.title: Common Scenario
docs.text:
You: Added new function parameter
You: Updated @param documentation
Run: rdoc && rtest
Result: Documentation updated + tests verify it works

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Always run after changing ANY roxygen comment 💡 Catches missing @export tags early 💡 Faster than full rcheck

docs.title: Safety Checks
docs.text:
• 🟢 Safe - only regenerates docs
  • Auto-backs up NAMESPACE (devtools handles this)

docs.title: 4️⃣ Full Check (Before Commit)
docs.text: When: Ready to commit, need to verify everything is perfect Time: ~60 minutes | Load: 🟡 Medium | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
rcycle               # Full cycle: doc → test → check
# OR (step by step)
rdoc && rtest && rcheck

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Ready to commit → rcycle → 60 min wait → ✅ 0 errors/warnings/notes

docs.title: What This Does
docs.text:
1. ⏱️ [5s] Documents package
  2. ⏱️ [2-4min] Runs tests
  3. ⏱️ [30-60min] Full R CMD check

docs.title: ADHD Strategy for Long Wait
docs.text:
• ⏰ Set timer → focus 60 for focus timer
  • 🎯 Switch context → Work on different package
  • ☕ Take break → Perfect time for lunch/walk
  • 📧 Other tasks → Email, admin work

docs.title: Decision Points
docs.text:
• ✅ 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes → COMMIT! 🎉
  • ⚠️ Warnings/notes → Investigate (might be OK)
  • ❌ Errors → Fix, run rcheck again

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Run this before ANY git commit 💡 Use rcheckfast for quicker check (skips examples/vignettes) 💡 NEVER commit with errors

docs.title: What Could Go Wrong?
docs.text:
• Check fails → Read error messages carefully
  • Takes forever → Normal! R CMD check is thorough
  • Interrupted → Just re-run to continue

docs.title: 5️⃣ Quick Commit Workflow
docs.text: When: Tests pass, ready to save work to git Time: ~3 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
# Option 1: Quick (if already checked)
git add . && git commit -m "message"

# Option 2: Safe (docs + tests + commit)
rdoc && rtest && git add . && git commit -m "message"

# Option 3: Ultra-safe (full check + commit)
rdoc && rtest && rcheck && git add . && git commit -m "message"

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Code ready → git commit → Done in 30s

docs.title: Commit Message Templates
docs.text:
# Feature
git commit -m "feat: add sensitivity analysis function"

# Bug fix
git commit -m "fix: handle NA values in mediation estimate"

# Documentation
git commit -m "docs: update README with new examples"

# Tests
git commit -m "test: add tests for interaction effects"

# Refactor
git commit -m "refactor: simplify bootstrap algorithm"

docs.title: Decision Tree
docs.text:
Did you run rcheck?
├─ Yes → git add . && git commit -m "message"
├─ No → rdoc && rtest then commit (safer)
└─ Not sure → Full check first (safest)

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Commit often (every 30-60 min of work) 💡 Small commits = easier to undo 💡 Use clear messages (future you will thank you!)

docs.title: Safety Checks
docs.text:
• Always run tests before committing
  • Can undo with git reset HEAD~1 if needed

docs.title: 6️⃣ Fix Failing Tests
docs.text: When: Tests are red, need to debug Time: Varies | Load: 🟡 Medium | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Step 1: Identify the Problem (2 min)
docs.text:
rtest                # Run tests, read error messages

Look for:

  • Which test file failed? (test-*.R)
  • Which expectation failed? (expect_equal, etc.)
  • What was expected vs actual?

docs.title: Step 2: Run Single Test (1 min)
docs.text:
# Run specific test file in R:
devtools::test_file("tests/testthat/test-myfunction.R")

docs.title: Step 3: Interactive Debugging (varies)
docs.text:
rload                # Load package
# Then in R console:
# debug(myfunction)
# Run test interactively

docs.title: Step 4: Fix and Verify (2 min)
docs.text:
# Fix the code
rtest                # Re-run all tests

docs.title: Common Test Failures
docs.text:
1. "Error: object not found"

  • Cause: Function not exported or loaded
  • Fix: Add @export tag, run rdoc && rtest

2. "Expected X but got Y"

  • Cause: Logic error or outdated test
  • Fix: Check function logic or update test

3. "Test times out"

  • Cause: Infinite loop or very slow code
  • Fix: Add timeout or optimize code

docs.title: ADHD-Friendly Debug Loop
docs.text:
1. Read error (30s)
2. Hypothesize fix (1 min)
3. Make ONE small change
4. Test immediately with `rtest`
5. Repeat until green

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Only fix ONE test at a time 💡 Use browser() for interactive debugging 💡 Take breaks if frustrated

docs.title: 7️⃣ Where Am I? (Context Check)
docs.text: When: Lost context, can't remember what you were doing Time: ~30 seconds | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
pwd                  # Show current directory
rpkg                 # Package info & status
git status           # Check git status

docs.title: Visual Output
docs.text:
rpkg → Shows:
- 📦 R package name + version
- 📊 Package description
- 🔧 Git branch

docs.title: Quick Recovery Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Run pwd → See where you are
  • [ ] Run rpkg → Package information
  • [ ] Run git status → Check git status
  • [ ] Check .STATUS file for next action

docs.title: Common Scenarios
docs.text:
"I forgot what I was working on"

pwd                  # Current directory
rpkg                 # Package info
cat .STATUS          # Check status file

"I don't remember what this package does"

rpkg                 # Package info
cat DESCRIPTION      # Read full description

"Did I make changes?"

git status           # Git status
git diff             # See changes

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Start every session with rpkg 💡 Keep .STATUS file updated 💡 Use git status frequently

docs.title: 8️⃣ Focus Mode (Deep Work)
docs.text: When: Need concentration, minimize distractions Time: Setup < 1 min | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
focus                # Minimize distractions
focus 25             # Focus + 25-min timer (Pomodoro)
unfocus              # Restore notifications

docs.title: What focus Does
docs.text:
1. ✅ Turns off macOS notifications
  2. ✅ Closes Slack, Mail, Messages
  3. ✅ Starts optional timer
  4. ✅ Announces when session ends

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Need focus → focus 25 → Work uninterrupted → Timer alert → Break

docs.title: Recommended Focus Workflows
docs.text:
Pomodoro (25 min)

f25                  # 25-minute focus timer
# Work for 25 min
# Timer alerts when done
# Take 5-min break

Deep Work (50 min)

f50                  # 50-minute deep work timer
# Work for 50 min
# Timer alerts when done
# Take 10-15 min break

Custom Duration

focus 90             # Custom 90-minute session
# Work until timer ends

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Use f25 or f50 aliases for common durations 💡 Use during rcheck 60-min wait 💡 Take regular breaks to maintain focus

docs.title: After Focus Session
docs.text:
# Update status and commit progress
git add . && git commit -m "Progress on X"

docs.title: 9️⃣ Start New Feature
docs.text: When: Beginning new function or feature Time: ~2 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: [ ] 1. Context Setup (30s)
docs.text:
pwd                  # Verify location
rpkg                 # Check package info
git status           # Check git status

docs.title: [ ] 2. Create Function File (30s)
docs.text:
# Create R/myfunction.R manually
# OR use usethis:
usethis::use_r("myfunction")

docs.title: [ ] 3. Create Test File (30s)
docs.text:
# Create tests/testthat/test-myfunction.R
# OR use usethis:
usethis::use_test("myfunction")

docs.title: [ ] 4. Document Template (30s)
docs.text:
Add roxygen skeleton:

#' Function Title
#'
#' @param x Description
#' @return Description
#' @export
#' @examples
#' myfunction(x = 1)
myfunction <- function(x) {
  # TODO: Implement
}

docs.title: [ ] 5. First Test (30s)
docs.text:
test_that("myfunction works", {
  result <- myfunction(x = 1)
  expect_true(!is.null(result))
})

docs.title: [ ] 6. Verify Setup
docs.text:
rload && rtest       # Load + test
# Should load successfully, test might fail (that's OK!)

docs.title: Quick Start Template
docs.text:
# Create files, then verify:
rload && rtest

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Start with test first (TDD approach) 💡 Make smallest working version 💡 Commit early: git commit -m "feat: add myfunction skeleton"

docs.title: 🔟 What Did I Break? (Emergency Recovery)
docs.text: When: Something broke and you're not sure what Time: Varies | Load: 🔴 Hard | Safety: 🟡 Careful

docs.title: Step 1: Assess Damage
docs.text:
pwd                  # Where am I?
git status           # What changed?
rtest                # Do tests pass?

docs.title: Step 2: Identify Problem
docs.text:
Tests failing?

rtest                # Run tests
# Read error messages carefully
# Jump to workflow #6 (Fix Failing Tests)

Package won't load?

rload                # Try to load
# Read error messages
# Common: syntax error, missing dependency

Git issues?

git status           # Git status
git log --oneline -5 # Recent commits

docs.title: Option A: Recent Changes (Most Common)
docs.text:
# Undo last commit (keeps changes)
git reset HEAD~1
# Fix the issue
rtest                # Verify tests pass
git add . && git commit -m "fix: ..."

docs.title: Option B: Code Error
docs.text:
# Use editor to fix syntax error
# Then:
rload                # Try loading again
rtest                # Run tests

docs.title: Option C: Clean Build (Last Resort)
docs.text:
# Clean and rebuild
rm -rf man/ NAMESPACE
rdoc && rtest        # Regenerate docs + test

docs.title: Prevention Checklist
docs.text:
• ✅ Run tests before commits
  • ✅ Commit frequently (small changes)
  • ✅ Use version control
  • ✅ Test after major changes

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Don't panic - almost everything is reversible 💡 Read error messages slowly (pause before acting) 💡 Ask for help: cc (Claude Code) or colleagues

docs.title: When to Ask for Help
docs.text:
• 🔴 Spent > 30 min stuck
  • 🔴 Don't understand error message
  • 🔴 Afraid of making it worse

docs.title: 🎯 Quick Decision Tree
docs.text:
Use this when you're not sure what to do:

What do you want to do?

├─ Just made code changes
│  └─ Run: rtest
│
├─ Starting work on package
│  └─ Run: rload && rtest
│
├─ Changed documentation
│  └─ Run: rdoc && rtest
│
├─ Ready to commit
│  ├─ Did full check? → git add . && git commit -m "msg"
│  └─ Not sure → rcheck then commit
│
├─ Tests are failing
│  └─ See workflow #6 (Fix Failing Tests)
│
├─ Don't know where I am
│  └─ Run: rpkg
│
├─ Need to focus
│  └─ Run: f25 or f50
│
├─ Starting new feature
│  └─ See workflow #9 (Start New Feature)
│
└─ Something broke
   └─ See workflow #10 (Emergency Recovery)

docs.title: ⏱️ Time-Based Quick Reference
docs.text:
"I have 5 minutes"

  • Run rtest (quick test)
  • Check rpkg (context)
  • Review .STATUS file

"I have 15 minutes"

  • Run rload && rtest
  • Fix one failing test
  • Quick commit

"I have 30 minutes"

  • Run rdoc && rtest
  • Start new feature
  • Focus session with f25

"I have 60+ minutes"

  • Run full rcheck
  • Deep work with f50 or focus 90
  • Multiple test-fix cycles

docs.title: Managing Wait Times
docs.text:
• Tests running (2-4 min)? → Perfect for coffee/bathroom
  • R CMD check (60 min)? → Switch to different task
  • Stuck debugging? → Take a 5-min break

docs.title: Preventing Context Loss
docs.text:
• Start every session: Check rpkg and .STATUS
  • End every session: Update .STATUS file
  • Commit frequently: Small commits = less to lose

docs.title: Reducing Decision Fatigue
docs.text:
• Use command chains: rload && rtest, rdoc && rtest
  • Follow workflows: Don't invent, follow the guide
  • Set timers: f25, f50, or focus commands

docs.title: Building Habits
docs.text:
• Morning ritual: rpkg → rload && rtest → check output
  • Before commit: rcheck → wait → commit
  • After break: rpkg → review .STATUS → resume

docs.title: 🚨 Common Mistakes & Fixes
docs.text: Mistake Why Bad Fix Skip testing Breaks accumulate Always run rtest No documentation Future you confused Run rdoc && rtest after changes Large commits Hard to debug Commit every 30-60 min Commit with errors Broken code in history Always test first Work without breaks Burnout, mistakes Use f25 or f50 timers Ignore .STATUS Lose context Update .STATUS regularly

docs.title: Connects to .STATUS Files
docs.text:
• Keep .STATUS updated with current progress
  • Check .STATUS at start of each session
  • Use for context when switching projects

docs.title: Works with Help System

  • Need reminder? Review this quick wins guide

docs.title: Pairs with Focus Tools
docs.text:
• f25 / f50 → Pomodoro/deep work timers
  • focus <min> → Custom duration focus sessions
  • win → Log accomplishments

docs.title: 🎉 Success Patterns
docs.text:

rpkg → rload && rtest → Coffee while tests run → Review results → Code

docs.title: 🔍 Workspace Audit Guide
docs.text:
Quick Start: Run ma for a complete daily health check

Last Updated: 2025-12-14 | Version: 1.0 | Source: zsh-claude-workflow v1.5.0

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Four new commands for maintaining workspace hygiene across all projects. Originally a standalone tool (workspace-auditor), now merged into zsh-claude-workflow for better integration.

Command Alias Purpose Frequency git-audit ga Find dirty/unpushed repos Daily file-audit fa Find large files (>50MB) Weekly activity-heat ah 7-day activity heatmap Daily morning-audit ma Full workspace check Daily

docs.title: 🔴 git-audit — Repository Health
docs.text: Scans ~/projects (depth 3) for repositories with uncommitted changes or unpushed commits.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
ga                  # Full audit with file lists
ga -q               # Quick summary only (recommended for daily use)
ga -a               # Show clean repos too
ga ~/code           # Audit specific directory

docs.title: Output Example
docs.text:
================
Git Repository Audit
================

⚠ research/mediation-planning — uncommitted changes
    M  R/analysis.R
    M  manuscript/draft.qmd
⚠ r-packages/active/medfit — uncommitted changes
    M  R/fit_model.R
    ?? tests/test-edge-cases.R
ℹ dev-tools/obsidian-cli-ops — unpushed commits
    + abc1234 feat: add new search command

Summary: 9 dirty, 1 unpushed
⚠ Consider a cleanup commit spree!

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Default Description PROJECTS_DIR ~/projects Base directory to scan GIT_AUDIT_DEPTH 3 How deep to search for .git

docs.title: Integration with Workflow
docs.text:
# Morning routine
ga -q               # Quick check
# If issues found:
cd ~/projects/problem-repo
gs                  # git status
qcommit "WIP: save progress"  # Quick commit

docs.title: 🐘 file-audit — Large File Detection
docs.text: Finds files over 50MB that may need cleanup, archiving, or .gitignore entries.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
fa                  # Find files >50MB in ~/projects
fa -s 100M          # Find files >100MB
fa -s 10M ~/data    # Audit data folder with lower threshold

docs.title: Output Example
docs.text:
========================
Large File Audit (>50M)
========================

127M  r-packages/active/dataprep/inst/extdata/census.csv
 89M  research/mediation-planning/data/raw/survey_2024.rds
 67M  apps/examark/public/assets/video-tutorial.mp4

Found: 3 files
⚠ Consider archiving or adding to .gitignore

docs.title: Exclusions (Automatic)
docs.text:
These directories are always skipped:

  • .git/
  • node_modules/
  • .venv/
  • __pycache__/
  • renv/

docs.title: Color Coding
docs.text: Color File Type Yellow Data files (.csv, .parquet, .rds, .RData, .feather) Blue Archives (.zip, .tar, .gz, .7z) Magenta Media (.pdf, .png, .jpg, .mp4) White Other

docs.title: Action Items
docs.text:
When large files are found:

  1. Data files → Add to .gitignore, use Git LFS, or move to cloud storage
  2. Archives → Delete if temporary, or move to external storage
  3. Media → Consider compression or external hosting

docs.title: 🔥 activity-heat — Project Heatmap
docs.text: Visual representation of which projects have the most recent file activity.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
ah                  # Last 7 days, top 10 projects
ah -d 30            # Last 30 days
ah -n 5             # Top 5 only
ah -d 1             # Today only

docs.text: Count Color Meaning 1-20 Green Normal activity 21-50 Yellow High activity 50+ Red Very high activity

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
1. Identify active work — See where you've been focusing
  2. Find forgotten projects — Low activity may mean stalled work
  3. Prioritize reviews — High activity projects may need commits
  4. Time tracking — Correlate with work logs

docs.title: 🌅 morning-audit — Daily Health Check
docs.text: Orchestrates all audit commands into a single daily report.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
ma                  # Quick terminal output
ma -s               # Save markdown report to ~/logs/audit/
ma -o               # Save and open report (macOS)
ma -q               # Minimal output

docs.title: What It Runs
docs.text:
1. git-audit -q — Find dirty/unpushed repos
  2. activity-heat -n 5 — Top 5 active projects
  3. file-audit — Large files (in saved report only)
  4. obs audit — Obsidian vault structure (if obs command available)

docs.title: Report Location
docs.text: Reports are saved to: ~/logs/audit/audit_report_YYYY-MM-DD.md

docs.text:

ma

# Option 2: Generate report for reference

docs.title: With obs (Obsidian CLI)
docs.text:
If you have obsidian-cli-ops installed, morning-audit automatically runs obs audit to check your Obsidian vault structure.

# Standalone Obsidian audit
obs audit

ma  # Includes obs audit automatically

docs.title: With Workflow Logging
docs.text:
Combine with workflow functions for comprehensive tracking:

# Start of day
ma                          # Check workspace health
startsession "morning"      # Start work session

# End of day

docs.text:

docs.title: Default Paths
docs.text:
All commands default to scanning ~/projects. Override with environment variables:

# In ~/.zshrc
export PROJECTS_DIR="$HOME/code"           # Change base directory
export GIT_AUDIT_DEPTH=4                    # Search deeper
export FILE_AUDIT_SIZE="100M"               # Higher threshold
export ACTIVITY_HEAT_DAYS=14                # Longer lookback
export ACTIVITY_HEAT_TOP=15                 # More results
export AUDIT_LOG_DIR="$HOME/Documents/logs" # Different log location

docs.title: Adding to PATH
docs.text:
The commands are in ~/projects/dev-tools/zsh-claude-workflow/commands/. If not already in PATH:

# In ~/.zshrc
export PATH="$HOME/projects/dev-tools/zsh-claude-workflow/commands:$PATH"

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text:
Add to your shell for quick access:

# Already included in zsh-claude-workflow install.sh
alias ga='git-audit'
alias fa='file-audit'
alias ah='activity-heat'
alias ma='morning-audit'

docs.text: Task Command Time Daily health check ma ~5s Quick git status ga -q ~3s Find large files fa ~5s See active projects ah ~3s Generate report ma -o ~10s Deep audit (30 days) ah -d 30 ~5s
